justification: "Participants are generally more inclined to choose the safest option when offered a choice between a 'safe' lottery ... and a 'risky' lottery" – indicating that a direct binary choice task is used to elicit risky‐choice preferences.

The article contrasts choice with pricing, noting that participants "specify how much they would be willing to pay to acquire" each lottery, labeling this WTP as a pricing method for the same preference.
It further states that people may indicate "how much they would be willing to accept to sell" a lottery, identifying WTA as another pricing instrument for risky preference.
The same sentence lists specifying "what dollar value would be equivalent to each option (certainty equivalent)" as an additional way of measuring the preference for risky prospects.

Hardisty et al. (2011) describe discount rates that "may be elicited by either choice-based approaches (indifference points inferred from binary choice)", showing a binary SS-LL choice as a measure of intertemporal preference.

The same review notes that discounting can be measured through "matching (discount rates inferred from the SS value equated to the LL value)", identifying the matching/indifference-point technique as a measure.

Hardisty et al. (2011) also mention "adaptive staircase procedures that titrate the value or delay of the options until choices made in sequence switch", naming the adaptive staircase as another instrument for assessing discounting.

In the Methods the authors "manipulated the response format – binary choice and willingness-to-pay judgments – within subjects" to study intertemporal choices, clearly using WTP pricing to measure delay discounting.
